title: Drumkeeragh Forest Walks

images.title: Albert Bridge / Drumkeeragh forest (1)
images.caption: Part of the forest (to the northwest of the entrance) has been cut for timber. The felled area is now being covered by bracken and heater.

images.title: Foxgloves, Drumkeeragh forest by Albert Bridge, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Foxgloves, Drumkeeragh forest

images.title: Albert Bridge / Bracken, Drumkeeragh forest
images.caption: Drumkeeragh forest. Autumn-tinted bracken growing by the path in the middle of the forest.

images.title: Albert Bridge / Drumkeeragh forest (2)
images.caption: A narrow path close to a part of the forest re-planted after felling.

images.title: Sheugh, Drumkeeragh forest by Albert Bridge, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sheugh, Drumkeeragh forest

images.title: Albert Bridge / Drumkeeragh forest (3)
images.caption: The descent towards the south/southwestern side of the forest.

description: This expansive area of woodland is located near Ballynahinch on the slopes of Slieve Croob. The mixed coniferous woodland includes mainly sitka spruce but with Norway spruce, western red cedar, European larch, Douglas fir and Corsican pines also present. There's miles of peaceful woodland paths with views of Strangford Lough, Scrabo Tower, Antrim Hills and the Sperrins from the high points. You can start your walk from the car parking area on the western side of the woods. To continue your walking in the area head west to climb to Slieve Croob where you can enjoy more fabulous views over the area. To the north east there's Ballynahinch and the splendid Montalto Estate to explore.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To the south there's Castlewellan Forest Park where you'll find miles of great trails around the lake and the national Arboretum of Northern Ireland.
